chapter.htmlHeader: HIV diagnosis in people with symptoms

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I suspect HIV infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider the possibility of HIV infection in a person presenting with one or more of the following:
    • Common symptoms or infections that are unusually severe, prolonged, recurrent, or unexplained.
    • Conditions related to immunosuppression, such as oral candidiasis or shingles.
    • Glandular fever-like illness.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis).
    • Lymphadenopathy of unknown origin.
    • Pyrexia of unknown origin.
    • Weight loss of more than 10 kg.
    • Risk factors for HIV, such as living in, working in, or coming from a high prevalence area; sex between men; and injecting drug use.
  • Be aware that infants most often present with:
    • Failure to thrive, and/or
    • Pneumocystis pneumonia, or
    • Cytomegalovirus disease, or
    • HIV encephalopathy.
  • After the first year of life, consider HIV infection in children presenting with:
    • Recurrent infections such as upper respiratory tract infections.
    • Severe presentations of common childhood infections.
    • Chronic diarrhoea.
    • Herpes zoster.
    • Severe pneumonia.
    • Tuberculosis.
    • Lymphadenopathy.
    • Any AIDS-defining condition.
  • For further information on primary HIV infection and conditions associated with established HIV infection see the sections on:
    • Primary HIV infection.
    • Longstanding HIV infection.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Primary HIV infection
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Primary HIV infection or HIV seroconversion illness occurs in the first few weeks following infection with HIV (usually between 10 days and 6 weeks) and can be mild or severe.
  • Clinical features associated with primary HIV infection develop in over 60% of people, can be non-specific, and include:
    • Fever, sore throat, maculopapular rash, malaise, lethargy, arthralgia, myalgia, lymphadenopathy, and oral, genital or perianal ulcers.
    • Less commonly, headache, meningitis, cranial nerve palsies, diarrhoea, and weight loss.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Longstanding HIV infection
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Conditions associated with longstanding HIV infection can be subtle and people may remain well for some time before developing another condition. Consider HIV if a person has had more than one of the following in the past 3 years, or has had conditions that are severe or resistant to treatment.

Constitutional symptoms

  • Constitutional symptoms may be due to HIV infection itself, a related opportunistic infection (such as tuberculosis), or malignancy (such as lymphoma), and include:
    • Flu-like symptoms.
    • Fever.
    • Weight loss.
    • Sweats.
    • Lymphadenopathy.

Respiratory conditions

  • Opportunistic respiratory infections such as pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), tuberculosis, bacterial lower respiratory tract infections; and occasionally Kaposi's sarcoma or lymphomas can result in symptoms including cough, sweats, breathlessness, and weight loss.
    • PCP is a life-threatening condition that can be difficult to identify at onset and is typically insidious over several weeks.
      • Symptoms include fever (in most but not all people), persistent dry cough of a few weeks’ duration, increasing breathlessness, decreasing exercise tolerance, chest discomfort, and difficulty in taking a full breath.
      • Signs include fine crackles (although the chest may be clear, especially in early infection) and a drop in oxygen saturation on exertion.
      • PCP can be fatal if diagnosed late.
    • Tuberculosis (TB) and atypical mycobacterial disease
      • TB is a common presenting condition in HIV. Atypical mycobacterial disease (such as Mycobacterium avium intracellulare) is less common and is associated with advanced HIV infection.
      • Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain.
  • For further information, see the CKS topics on Chest infections - adult, Cough, and Tuberculosis.

Neurological and visual conditions

  • HIV infection is associated with many neurological and visual problems including:
    • Cryptococcal meningitis — may present as subacute meningitis with headache and fever, acute confusional state, or cranial nerve palsies.
      • Typical symptoms and signs of meningism may be absent.
    • Cerebral toxoplasmosis — occurs owing to reactivation of previous toxoplasmosis infection.
      • May present with confusion, headache, personality change, fever, fits, and focal neurological signs.
    • Cerebral lymphoma (in advanced HIV disease).
      • May present with confusion, lethargy, personality change, headache, fever, fits, and focal neurological signs.
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis occurs owing to reactivation of previously acquired infection and can lead to loss of vision.
      • Prognosis improves with earlier diagnosis.
      • Symptoms include floaters (due to inflammatory cells in the vitreous), reduced vision, flashing lights, and scotomas.

Cancers

  • HIV infection is associated with increased risk of malignancy including:
    • Lymphoma
      • Lymphoma can present with weight loss, fevers, night sweats, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal masses (lymph nodes, hepatomegaly, or splenomegaly).
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Haematological cancers - recognition and referral.
    • Kaposi's sarcoma
      • Kaposi's sarcoma is the most common tumour in people with HIV infection and typically presents with dark purple or brown intradermal skin lesions that look like bruises but feel firmer.
      • Tumours may occur anywhere on the skin or oropharynx — infiltration of the lungs or gut is rare but can be life threatening.
    • Cervical cancer
      • Cervical cancer can present with vaginal bleeding or discharge. For further information, see the CKS on Cervical cancer and HPV.
      • Abnormal cervical cytology may be a marker for underlying HIV infection.

Skin conditions

  • In addition to Kaposi’s sarcoma, HIV infection is associated with many common skin conditions. These are often unusually severe, recurrent, or resistant to treatment, and include:
    • Fungal skin and nail infections
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Fungal skin infection - body and groin, Fungal skin infection - foot, Fungal skin infection - scalp, Fungal nail infection, and Pityriasis versicolor.
    • Viral infections such as herpes simplex (especially if the ulcers are unusually large or persistent), molluscum contagiosum, shingles (especially if more than one dermatome is affected), and warts.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Herpes simplex - genital, Herpes simplex - ocular, Herpes simplex - oral, Molluscum contagiosum, Shingles, and Warts and verrucae.
    • Bacterial infections such as impetigo and folliculitis.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Impetigo.
    • Seborrhoeic dermatitis and psoriasis
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Seborrhoeic dermatitis and Psoriasis.

Oral conditions

  • HIV infection is associated with:
    • Oral candidiasis
      • Typically presents with thick white plaques covering the buccal mucosa that can be scraped off. Soreness of the mouth or pain on swallowing (odynophagia) may also be present.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Candida - oral.
    • Aphthous ulcers
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Aphthous ulcer.
    • Oral hairy leukoplakia
      • Typically presents as asymptomatic corrugated whitish, hairy patches on the side of the tongue that cannot be scraped off (in contrast to oral candidiasis) and is pathognomic of immunosuppression.
    • Kaposi's sarcoma
      • Most often affects the hard and soft palate, gingiva, and dorsal tongue with plaques or tumours of variable colour from non-pigmented to brownish-red or purple.
    • Gingivitis
      • Causes swelling and erythema of the gum margins that are usually painful and bleed on tooth brushing or flossing.
      • See the CKS topic on Gingivitis and periodontitis for further information.
    • Dental abscess
      • Typically presents with rapid onset of severe dental pain and may be associated with an unpleasant taste in the mouth, fever, and malaise.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Dental abscess.

Gastrointestinal conditions

  • HIV infection is associated with:
    • Oesophageal candidiasis
      • Symptoms include retrosternal pain or dysphagia. Oral candidiasis is also likely to be present.
    • Diarrhoea
      • Diarrhoea is very common and may be persistent and mild or acute and severe.
      • Infection due to bacteria, protozoa (such as Cryptosporidium), mycobacteria, or viruses; malignancy (such as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma or Kaposi's sarcoma), or the direct effects of HIV can all result in diarrhoea.
      • Often no specific causative organism is identified.
    • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C infection
      • Co-infection with hepatitis B or C is common and increases the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C.

Genital conditions

  • Consider HIV infection in anyone presenting with severe or difficult-to-treat genital candida, genital herpes, or genital warts.
    • For further information, see the CKS topics on Candida - female genital, Herpes simplex - genital, and Warts - anogenital.

Haematological conditions

  • Consider HIV infection in anyone with unexplained abnormalities on full blood count such as neutropenia, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, or other blood dyscrasias.

subChapters.fullItemName: How should I assess a person with suspected HIV infection?
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected HIV infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history, asking about:
    • Symptoms that may be HIV-related such as fever, weight loss, sweats, diarrhoea, lymphadenopathy, skin rashes, cough, oral candida, and aphthous ulcers.
    • Possible risk factors.
    • Past medical history, including hospital admissions as these may be related to HIV infection.
  • Examine the person for:
    • Rash — in particular a generalized maculopapular rash.
    • Lymphadenopathy, particularly in extra-inguinal sites.
    • Signs of immunocompromise such as oral candidiasis.
    • Signs of HIV-related conditions, being alert for those that are serious or life threatening, such as:
      • Pneumocystis pneumonia.
      • Tuberculosis — for further information, see the CKS topic on Tuberculosis.
      • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.
      • Lymphoma — for further information, see the CKS topic on Haematological cancers - recognition and referral.
      • Kaposi's sarcoma.
  • Review the person's medical records for evidence of previous HIV-associated problems.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I test for HIV?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Check the persons understanding of HIV.
  • Decide with the person whether urgent assessment by a specialist is required and whether HIV testing should be carried out in primary care or elsewhere.
    • Arrange admission for urgent specialist assessment if there is concern about the possibility of a serious HIV-related condition such as Pneumocystis pneumonia.
    • If admission is not required, discuss the timing between testing and availability of the result, as this may alter some people's preferences as to where they are tested:
      • Timing of test results varies depending on local laboratory facilities — some services may be able to provide results more rapidly if requested. For further information on specific tests, see the section on Tests for HIV infection.
      • Specialist services such as genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinics usually provide results on the same day.
      • Some organizations, such as the Terence Higgins Trust (an HIV/AIDS charity) offer testing services with results available within the hour. Further information (including on online ordering of self-tests and postal test kits) is available on their website.
    • Consider referral to GUM for testing if the person has mental health problems or additional counselling needs as specialist input may be required.
  • Pre-test counselling should include discussion of:
    • The benefits of HIV testing:
      • If the test is negative, the person can be reassured and given advice on reducing the risk of HIV infection.
      • If the test is positive, effective treatment can help prevent HIV-related illness and ensure that infection is not transmitted to contacts or in pregnancy.
    • Details of how the result will be given:
      • Check you have correct contact details, the preferred method of contact, and whether there may be any problems with leaving messages or talking.
      • If possible, arrange an appointment for the result to be given — negative results may be discussed by telephone.
    • The significance of the window period as a repeat test may be necessary.
      • The window period is the time between becoming infected and antibodies appearing — HIV antibodies usually appear 4–6 weeks after infection but can take up to 12 weeks.
    • The importance of confidentiality and that the result will need to be recorded in medical records.
  • Ensure that informed consent has been given for the test — written consent is not required.
  • If the person is at risk sexually and/or through injecting drug use:
    • Refer for further assessment (including screening for hepatitis and other sexually transmitted infections) and support to the local GUM clinic or substance misuse service.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I give the result of an HIV test?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If possible, give results in a face-to-face consultation.
  • If the test is negative:
    • Consider if a further test is needed to cover the window period — seek specialist advice from genito-urinary medicine (GUM) if unsure.
    • Reinforce advice about minimizing risk where appropriate.
  • If the test is positive:
    • The laboratory is likely to telephone the result through and ask for a repeat sample.
    • Emphasize the positive aspects — effective treatment can help prevent HIV-related illness and ensure that infection is not transmitted to contacts or in pregnancy.
    • Explain the referral process — for further information, see the section on New diagnosis of HIV.
    • Discuss concerns and sources of support.
    • Arrange follow up within the next few days as the person is likely to have additional questions.
  • Non-attendance for positive results:
    • Follow the practice's usual recall process.
    • If recall is unsuccessful, seek advice from a local GUM or HIV clinic, as they will have experience in managing this.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Recommendations on assessment of a person with suspected HIV are based on the clinical guidelines UK guidelines for HIV testing 2008 [BHIVA, 2008b], HIV in primary care. A practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [Matthews, 2016], British HIV Association/British Infection Association guidelines on the management of opportunistic infection in people living with HIV [BHIVA, 2019b], and Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in Adults and Adolescents with HIV [CDC, 2019]; a statement from the British Association of Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) and the UK Chief Medical Officers' Expert Advisory Group on AIDS (EAGA) BASHH/EAGA statement on HIV window period [BASHH, 2014]; and expert opinion in review articles [Goldschmidt, 2016; Kirkham, 2017; Lebari, 2019; BMJ Best Practice, 2020b; BMJ Best Practice, 2020a].

Constitutional symptoms

  • The UK National Guidelines for HIV testing [BHIVA, 2008b] recommend that people with glandular fever-like syndrome, pyrexia of unknown origin, weight loss, or lymphadenopathy of unknown cause should be offered an HIV test.
  • At the time of writing (July 2020), the British HIV Association (BHIVA) Guidelines Subcommittee, the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) Clinical Effectiveness Group, and the British Infection Association (BIA) Adult HIV Testing guidelines were in the process of being updated.

Haematological problems

  • The UK National Guidelines for HIV testing [BHIVA, 2008b] recommend that an HIV test is offered to people with unexplained neutropenia, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, or other blood dyscrasias.

HIV testing

  • HIV testing using 'fourth generation' tests are recommended in guidance from BHIVA, EAGA, and the Medical Foundation for HIV & Sexual Health (MEDFASH) [BHIVA, 2008b; BASHH, 2014; Matthews, 2016].
    • At the time of writing (July 2020) the BHIVA Guidelines Subcommittee, the BASHH Clinical Effectiveness Group, and the BIA Adult HIV Testing Guidelines (2020) were in the process of being updated.
  • Fourth generation assays testing for HIV antibodies and p24 antigen in venous samples will detect the majority of people infected with HIV at 4 weeks after exposure [Matthews, 2016; NICE, 2016].
    • A negative result at 4 weeks post exposure is highly likely to exclude HIV infection — an additional HIV test at 8 weeks need only be considered following an exposure assessed as high risk for infection [BASHH, 2014].
    • The BASHH/EAGA statement on HIV window period states that people attending for HIV testing who identify a specific risk occurring less than 4 weeks previously, should not be made to wait before HIV testing — a fourth generation HIV test should be offered with repeat testing at 4 weeks from the time of last exposure.
    • Retesting at regular intervals is advised for those with ongoing risk of HIV [BASHH, 2014].
    • Testing for other sexually transmitted infections should be advised and people at risk of hepatitis B virus who are not immune should be immunized [BASHH, 2014].
